speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: He after honor hunts, I after love:
He leaves his friends, to dignify them more;
I leave myself, my friends, and all, for love.
Thou, Julia, thou hast metamorphis’d me,
Made me neglect my studies, lose my time,
War with good counsel, set the world at nought;
Made wit with musing weak, heart sick with thought.

scene.line: I must go send some better messenger:
I fear my Julia would not deign my lines,
Receiving them from such a worthless post.

scene.scenelocation: Verona. The garden of Julia’s house.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: And yet I would I had o’erlook’d the letter;
It were a shame to call her back again,
And pray her to a fault for which I chid her.
What ’fool is she, that knows I am a maid,
And would not force the letter to my view!
Since maids, in modesty, say “no” to that
Which they would have the profferer construe “ay.”
Fie, fie, how wayward is this foolish love,
That (like a testy babe) will scratch the nurse
And presently, all humbled, kiss the rod!
How churlishly I chid Lucetta hence,
When willingly I would have had her here!
How angerly I taught my brow to frown,
When inward joy enforc’d my heart to smile!
My penance is, to call Lucetta back
And ask remission for my folly past.
What ho! Lucetta!

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: Nay, would I were so ang’red with the same.
O hateful hands, to tear such loving words!
Injurious wasps, to feed on such sweet honey,
And kill the bees that yield it with your stings!
I’ll kiss each several paper for amends.
Look, here is writ “kind Julia.” Unkind Julia,
As in revenge of thy ingratitude,
I throw thy name against the bruising stones,
Trampling contemptuously on thy disdain.
And here is writ “love-wounded Proteus.”
Poor wounded name: my bosom as a bed
Shall lodge thee till thy wound be throughly heal’d;
And thus I search it with a sovereign kiss.
But twice, or thrice, was “Proteus” written down:
Be calm, good wind, blow not a word away
Till I have found each letter in the letter,
Except mine own name; that, some whirlwind bear
Unto a ragged, fearful, hanging rock,
And throw it thence into the raging sea.
Lo, here in one line is his name twice writ,
“Poor forlorn Proteus, passionate Proteus:
To the sweet Julia”—that I’ll tear away—
And yet I will not, sith so prettily
He couples it to his complaining names.
Thus will I fold them one upon another;
Now kiss, embrace, contend, do what you will.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Tell me, Panthino, what sad talk was that
Wherewith my brother held you in the cloister?

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: ’Twas of his nephew Proteus, your son.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Why, what of him?

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: He wond’red that your lordship
Would suffer him to spend his youth at home,
While other men, of slender reputation,
Put forth their sons to seek preferment out:
Some to the wars, to try their fortune there;
Some to discover islands far away;
Some to the studious universities.
For any or for all these exercises
He said that Proteus, your son, was meet;
And did request me to importune you
To let him spend his time no more at home,
Which would be great impeachment to his age,
In having known no travel in his youth.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Nor need’st thou much importune me to that
Whereon this month I have been hammering.
I have consider’d well his loss of time,
And how he cannot be a perfect man,
Not being tried and tutor’d in the world:
Experience is by industry achiev’d,
And perfected by the swift course of time.
Then tell me, whither were I best to send him?

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: I think your lordship is not ignorant
How his companion, youthful Valentine,
Attends the Emperor in his royal court.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: I know it well.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: ’Twere good, I think, your lordship sent him thither:
There shall he practice tilts and tournaments,
Hear sweet discourse, converse with noblemen,
And be in eye of every exercise
Worthy his youth and nobleness of birth.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: I like thy counsel; well hast thou advis’d;
And that thou mayst perceive how well I like it,
The execution of it shall make known:
Even with the speediest expedition
I will dispatch him to the Emperor’s court.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Tomorrow, may it please you, Don Alphonso
With other gentlemen of good esteem
Are journeying to salute the Emperor,
And to commend their service to his will.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Good company; with them shall Proteus go—

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Thus have I shunn’d the fire for fear of burning,
And drench’d me in the sea, where I am drown’d.
I fear’d to show my father Julia’s letter,
Lest he should take exceptions to my love,
And with the vantage of mine own excuse
Hath he excepted most against my love.
O, how this spring of love resembleth
The uncertain glory of an April day,
Which now shows all the beauty of the sun,
And by and by a cloud takes all away.

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: Sir, your glove.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Not mine: my gloves are on.

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: Why then this may be yours—for this is but one.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Ha? Let me see; ay, give it me, it’s mine:
Sweet ornament that decks a thing divine—
Ah, Silvia, Silvia!

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: Madam Silvia! Madam Silvia!

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: How now, sirrah?

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: She is not within hearing, sir.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Why, sir, who bade you call her?

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: Your worship, sir, or else I mistook.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Well—You’ll still be too forward.

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: And yet I was last chidden for being too slow.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Go to, sir; tell me, do you know Madam Silvia?

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: She that your worship loves?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Why, how know you that I am in love?

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: Marry, by these special marks: first, you have learn’d, like Sir Proteus, to wreathe your arms, like a malecontent; to relish a love-song, like a robin-redbreast; to walk alone, like one that had the pestilence; to sigh, like a schoolboy that had lost his A B C; to weep, like a young wench that had buried her grandam; to fast, like one that takes diet; to watch, like one that fears robbing; to speak puling, like a beggar at Hallowmas. You were wont, when you laugh’d, to crow like a cock; when you walk’d, to walk like one of the lions; when you fasted, it was presently after dinner; when you look’d sadly, it was for want of money: and now you are metamorphis’d with a mistress, that when I look on you, I can hardly think you my master.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Are all these things perceiv’d in me?

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: They are all perceiv’d without ye.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Without me? They cannot.

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: Without you? Nay, that’s certain; for without you were so simple, none else would: but you are so without these follies, that these follies are within you, and shine through you like the water in an urinal, that not an eye that sees you but is a physician to comment on your malady.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: But tell me: dost thou know my lady Silvia?

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: She that you gaze on so as she sits at supper?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Hast thou observ’d that? Even she I mean.

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: Why, sir, I know her not.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Dost thou know her by my gazing on her, and yet know’st her not?

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: Is she not hard-favor’d, sir?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Not so fair, boy, as well-favor’d.

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: Sir, I know that well enough.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: What dost thou know?

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: That she is not so fair as (of you) well favor’d.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: I mean that her beauty is exquisite, but her favor infinite.

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: That’s because the one is painted, and the other out of all count.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: How painted? And how out of count?

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: Marry, sir, so painted to make her fair, that no man counts of her beauty.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: How esteem’st thou me? I account of her beauty.

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: You never saw her since she was deform’d.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: How long hath she been deform’d?

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: Ever since you lov’d her.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: I have lov’d her ever since I saw her, and still I see her beautiful.

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: If you love her, you cannot see her.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Why?

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: Because Love is blind. O that you had mine eyes, or your own eyes had the lights they were wont to have when you chid at Sir Proteus for going ungarter’d!

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: What should I see then?

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: Your own present folly, and her passing deformity: for he, being in love, could not see to garter his hose; and you, being in love, cannot see to put on your hose.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Belike, boy, then you are in love—for last morning you could not see to wipe my shoes.

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: True, sir; I was in love with my bed. I thank you, you swing’d me for my love, which makes me the bolder to chide you for yours.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: In conclusion, I stand affected to her.

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: I would you were set, so your affection would cease.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Last night she enjoin’d me to write some lines to one she loves.

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: And have you?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: I have.

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: Are they not lamely writ?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: No, boy, but as well as I can do them.
O excellent motion! O exceeding puppet! Now will he interpret to her.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Madam and mistress, a thousand good morrows.

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: O, give ye good ev’n! Here’s a million of manners.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Sir Valentine and servant, to you two thousand.

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: He should give her interest, and she gives it him.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: As you enjoin’d me, I have writ your letter
Unto the secret, nameless friend of yours;
Which I was much unwilling to proceed in,
But for my duty to your ladyship.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: I thank you, gentle servant—’tis very clerkly done.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Now trust me, madam, it came hardly off;
For being ignorant to whom it goes,
I writ at random, very doubtfully.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Perchance you think too much of so much pains?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: No, madam; so it stead you, I will write
(Please you command) a thousand times as much;
And yet—

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: A pretty period! Well—I guess the sequel;
And yet I will not name it—and yet I care not—
And yet take this again—and yet I thank you—
Meaning henceforth to trouble you no more.

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: And yet you will; and yet another “yet.”

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: What means your ladyship? Do you not like it?

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Yes, yes; the lines are very quaintly writ,
But (since unwillingly) take them again.
Nay, take them.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Madam, they are for you.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Ay, ay; you writ them, sir, at my request,
But I will none of them; they are for you.
I would have had them writ more movingly.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Please you, I’ll write your ladyship another.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: And when it’s writ, for my sake read it over,
And if it please you, so; if not, why, so.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: If it please me, madam, what then?

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Why, if it please you, take it for your labor;
And so good morrow, servant.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Have patience, gentle Julia.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: I must, where is no remedy.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: When possibly I can, I will return.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: If you turn not, you will return the sooner.
Keep this remembrance for thy Julia’s sake.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Why then we’ll make exchange: here, take you this.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: And seal the bargain with a holy kiss.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Here is my hand for my true constancy;
And when that hour o’erslips me in the day
Wherein I sigh not, Julia, for thy sake,
The next ensuing hour some foul mischance
Torment me for my love’s forgetfulness!
My father stays my coming; answer not;
The tide is now—nay, not thy tide of tears,
That tide will stay me longer than I should.
Julia, farewell!

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Sir Proteus, you are stay’d for.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Go; I come, I come.
Alas, this parting strikes poor lovers dumb.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Launce, away, away! Aboard! Thy master is shipp’d, and thou art to post after with oars. What’s the matter? Why weep’st thou, man? Away, ass, you’ll lose the tide, if you tarry any longer.

speech.speaker: LAUNCE.
speech.line: It is no matter if the tied were lost; for it is the unkindest tied that ever any man tied.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: What’s the unkindest tide?

speech.speaker: LAUNCE.
speech.line: Why, he that’s tied here, Crab, my dog.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Tut, man, I mean thou’lt lose the flood, and in losing the flood, lose thy voyage, and in losing thy voyage, lose thy master, and in losing thy master, lose thy service, and in losing thy service—Why dost thou stop my mouth?

speech.speaker: LAUNCE.
speech.line: For fear thou shouldst lose thy tongue.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Where should I lose my tongue?

speech.speaker: LAUNCE.
speech.line: In thy tale.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: In thy tail!

speech.speaker: LAUNCE.
speech.line: Lose the tide, and the voyage, and the master, and the service, and the tied! Why, man, if the river were dry, I am able to fill it with my tears; if the wind were down, I could drive the boat with my sighs.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Come; come away, man—I was sent to call thee.

speech.speaker: LAUNCE.
speech.line: Sir—call me what thou dar’st.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Wilt thou go?

speech.speaker: LAUNCE.
speech.line: Well, I will go.

scene.scenelocation: Milan. A room in the Duke’s palace.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Servant, you are sad.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Indeed, madam, I seem so.

speech.speaker: THU.
speech.line: Seem you that you are not?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Happ’ly I do.

speech.speaker: THU.
speech.line: So do counterfeits.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: So do you.

speech.speaker: THU.
speech.line: What seem I that I am not?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Wise.

speech.speaker: THU.
speech.line: What instance of the contrary?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Your folly.

speech.speaker: THU.
speech.line: And how quote you my folly?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: I quote it in your jerkin.

speech.speaker: THU.
speech.line: My jerkin is a doublet.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Well then I’ll double your folly.

speech.speaker: THU.
speech.line: How?

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: What, angry, Sir Thurio? Do you change color?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Give him leave, madam, he is a kind of chameleon.

speech.speaker: THU.
speech.line: That hath more mind to feed on your blood than live in your air.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: You have said, sir.

speech.speaker: THU.
speech.line: Ay, sir, and done too—for this time.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: I know it well, sir; you always end ere you begin.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: A fine volley of words, gentlemen, and quickly shot off.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: ’Tis indeed, madam, we thank the giver.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Who is that, servant?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Yourself, sweet lady, for you gave the fire. Sir Thurio borrows his wit from your ladyship’s looks, and spends what he borrows kindly in your company.

speech.speaker: THU.
speech.line: Sir, if you spend word for word with me, I shall make your wit bankrupt.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: I know it well, sir; you have an exchequer of words and, I think, no other treasure to give your followers; for it appears by their bare liveries that they live by your bare words.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: No more, gentlemen, no more; here comes my father.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: This is the gentleman I told your ladyship
Had come along with me, but that his mistress
Did hold his eyes lock’d in her crystal looks.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Belike that now she hath enfranchis’d them
Upon some other pawn for fealty.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Nay sure, I think she holds them prisoners still.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Nay then he should be blind, and being blind,
How could he see his way to seek out you?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Why, lady, Love hath twenty pair of eyes.

speech.speaker: THU.
speech.line: They say that Love hath not an eye at all.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: To see such lovers, Thurio, as yourself:
Upon a homely object Love can wink.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Have done, have done; here comes the gentleman.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Welcome, dear Proteus! Mistress, I beseech you
Confirm his welcome with some special favor.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: His worth is warrant for his welcome hither,
If this be he you oft have wish’d to hear from.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Mistress, it is: sweet lady, entertain him
To be my fellow-servant to your ladyship.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Too low a mistress for so high a servant.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Not so, sweet lady, but too mean a servant
To have a look of such a worthy mistress.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Leave off discourse of disability.
Sweet lady, entertain him for your servant.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: My duty will I boast of, nothing else.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: And duty never yet did want his meed.
Servant, you are welcome to a worthless mistress.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: I’ll die on him that says so but yourself.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: That you are welcome?

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: That you are worthless.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Now tell me: how do all from whence you came?

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Your friends are well and have them much commended.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: And how do yours?

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: I left them all in health.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: How does your lady, and how thrives your love?

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: My tales of love were wont to weary you;
I know you joy not in a love-discourse.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Ay, Proteus, but that life is alter’d now:
I have done penance for contemning Love,
Whose high imperious thoughts have punish’d me
With bitter fasts, with penitential groans,
With nightly tears, and daily heart-sore sighs,
For in revenge of my contempt of love,
Love hath chas’d sleep from my enthralled eyes,
And made them watchers of mine own heart’s sorrow.
O gentle Proteus, Love’s a mighty lord,
And hath so humbled me as I confess
There is no woe to his correction,
Nor to his service no such joy on earth:
Now no discourse, except it be of love;
Now can I break my fast, dine, sup, and sleep,
Upon the very naked name of love.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Enough; I read your fortune in your eye.
Was this the idol that you worship so?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Even she; and is she not a heavenly saint?

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: No; but she is an earthly paragon.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Call her divine.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: I will not flatter her.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: O, flatter me; for love delights in praises.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: When I was sick, you gave me bitter pills,
And I must minister the like to you.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Then speak the truth by her; if not divine,
Yet let her be a principality,
Sovereign to all the creatures on the earth.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Except my mistress.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Sweet, except not any,
Except thou wilt except against my love.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Have I not reason to prefer mine own?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: And I will help thee to prefer her too:
She shall be dignified with this high honor—
To bear my lady’s train, lest the base earth
Should from her vesture chance to steal a kiss,
And of so great a favor growing proud,
Disdain to root the summer-swelling flow’r,
And make rough winter everlastingly.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Why, Valentine, what braggadism is this?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Pardon me, Proteus, all I can is nothing
To her, whose worth makes other worthies nothing:
She is alone.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Then let her alone.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Not for the world. Why, man, she is mine own,
And I as rich in having such a jewel
As twenty seas, if all their sand were pearl,
The water nectar, and the rocks pure gold.
Forgive me, that I do not dream on thee,
Because thou seest me dote upon my love.
My foolish rival, that her father likes
(Only for his possessions are so huge),
Is gone with her along, and I must after,
For love, thou know’st, is full of jealousy.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: But she loves you?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Ay, and we are betroth’d: nay more, our marriage hour,
With all the cunning manner of our flight,
Determin’d of—how I must climb her window,
The ladder made of cords, and all the means
Plotted and ’greed on for my happiness.
Good Proteus, go with me to my chamber,
In these affairs to aid me with thy counsel.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Go on before; I shall inquire you forth.
I must unto the road, to disembark
Some necessaries that I needs must use,
And then I’ll presently attend you.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Will you make haste?

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: I will.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: To leave my Julia—shall I be forsworn?
To love fair Silvia—shall I be forsworn?
To wrong my friend, I shall be much forsworn.
And ev’n that pow’r which gave me first my oath
Provokes me to this threefold perjury.
Love bade me swear, and Love bids me forswear.
O sweet-suggesting Love, if thou hast sinn’d,
Teach me, thy tempted subject, to excuse it!
At first I did adore a twinkling star,
But now I worship a celestial sun.
Unheedful vows may heedfully be broken,
And he wants wit that wants resolved will
To learn his wit t’ exchange the bad for better.
Fie, fie, unreverend tongue, to call her bad,
Whose sovereignty so oft thou hast preferr’d
With twenty thousand soul-confirming oaths.
I cannot leave to love, and yet I do;
But there I leave to love where I should love.
Julia I lose, and Valentine I lose:
If I keep them, I needs must lose myself;
If I lose them, thus find I by their loss—
For Valentine, myself; for Julia, Silvia.
I to myself am dearer than a friend,
For love is still most precious in itself,
And Silvia (witness heaven, that made her fair)
Shows Julia but a swarthy Ethiope.
I will forget that Julia is alive,
Rememb’ring that my love to her is dead;
And Valentine I’ll hold an enemy,
Aiming at Silvia as a sweeter friend.
I cannot now prove constant to myself,
Without some treachery us’d to Valentine.
This night he meaneth with a corded ladder
To climb celestial Silvia’s chamber-window,
Myself in counsel his competitor.
Now presently I’ll give her father notice
Of their disguising and pretended flight,
Who, all enrag’d, will banish Valentine;
For Thurio, he intends, shall wed his daughter;
But, Valentine being gone, I’ll quickly cross
By some sly trick blunt Thurio’s dull proceeding.
Love, lend me wings to make my purpose swift,
As thou hast lent me wit to plot this drift.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: Counsel, Lucetta; gentle girl, assist me;
And ev’n in kind love I do conjure thee,
Who art the table wherein all my thoughts
Are visibly character’d and engrav’d,
To lesson me and tell me some good mean
How with my honor I may undertake
A journey to my loving Proteus.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Alas, the way is wearisome and long.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: A true-devoted pilgrim is not weary
To measure kingdoms with his feeble steps;
Much less shall she that hath Love’s wings to fly,
And when the flight is made to one so dear,
Of such divine perfection, as Sir Proteus.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Better forbear till Proteus make return.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: O, know’st thou not his looks are my soul’s food?
Pity the dearth that I have pined in,
By longing for that food so long a time.
Didst thou but know the inly touch of love,
Thou wouldst as soon go kindle fire with snow
As seek to quench the fire of love with words.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: I do not seek to quench your love’s hot fire,
But qualify the fire’s extreme rage,
Lest it should burn above the bounds of reason.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: The more thou dam’st it up, the more it burns:
The current that with gentle murmur glides,
Thou know’st, being stopp’d, impatiently doth rage;
But when his fair course is not hindered,
He makes sweet music with th’ enamell’d stones,
Giving a gentle kiss to every sedge
He overtaketh in his pilgrimage;
And so by many winding nooks he strays
With willing sport to the wild ocean.
Then let me go, and hinder not my course:
I’ll be as patient as a gentle stream,
And make a pastime of each weary step,
Till the last step have brought me to my love,
And there I’ll rest, as after much turmoil
A blessed soul doth in Elysium.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: But in what habit will you go along?

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: Not like a woman, for I would prevent
The loose encounters of lascivious men:
Gentle Lucetta, fit me with such weeds
As may beseem some well-reputed page.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Why then your ladyship must cut your hair.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: No, girl, I’ll knit it up in silken strings,
With twenty odd-conceited true-love knots:
To be fantastic may become a youth
Of greater time than I shall show to be.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: What fashion, madam, shall I make your breeches?

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: That fits as well as “Tell me, good my lord,
What compass will you wear your farthingale?”
Why, ev’n what fashion thou best likes, Lucetta.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: You must needs have them with a codpiece, madam.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: Out, out, Lucetta, that will be ill-favor’d.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: A round hose, madam, now’s not worth a pin,
Unless you have a codpiece to stick pins on.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: Lucetta, as thou lov’st me, let me have
What thou think’st meet, and is most mannerly.
But tell me, wench, how will the world repute me
For undertaking so unstaid a journey?
I fear me it will make me scandaliz’d.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: If you think so, then stay at home and go not.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: Nay, that I will not.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Then never dream on infamy, but go.
If Proteus like your journey when you come,
No matter who’s displeas’d when you are gone:
I fear me he will scarce be pleas’d withal.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: That is the least, Lucetta, of my fear:
A thousand oaths, an ocean of his tears,
And instances of infinite of love,
Warrant me welcome to my Proteus.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: All these are servants to deceitful men.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: Base men, that use them to so base effect!
But truer stars did govern Proteus’ birth:
His words are bonds, his oaths are oracles,
His love sincere, his thoughts immaculate,
His tears pure messengers sent from his heart,
His heart as far from fraud as heaven from earth.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Pray heav’n he prove so when you come to him!

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: Now, as thou lov’st me, do him not that wrong,
To bear a hard opinion of his truth:
Only deserve my love by loving him,
And presently go with me to my chamber,
To take a note of what I stand in need of,
To furnish me upon my longing journey.
All that is mine I leave at thy dispose,
My goods, my lands, my reputation;
Only, in lieu thereof, dispatch me hence.
Come; answer not; but to it presently,
I am impatient of my tarriance.

scene.scenelocation: Milan. An anteroom in the Duke’s palace.
scene.line: Now tell me, Proteus, what’s your will with me?

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: My gracious lord, that which I would discover
The law of friendship bids me to conceal,
But when I call to mind your gracious favors
Done to me (undeserving as I am),
My duty pricks me on to utter that
Which else no worldly good should draw from me.
Know, worthy prince, Sir Valentine, my friend,
This night intends to steal away your daughter;
Myself am one made privy to the plot.
I know you have determin’d to bestow her
On Thurio, whom your gentle daughter hates,
And should she thus be stol’n away from you,
It would be much vexation to your age.
Thus, for my duty’s sake, I rather chose
To cross my friend in his intended drift,
Than, by concealing it, heap on your head
A pack of sorrows which would press you down,
Being unprevented, to your timeless grave.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Proteus, I thank thee for thine honest care,
Which to requite, command me while I live.
This love of theirs myself have often seen,
Haply when they have judg’d me fast asleep,
And oftentimes have purpos’d to forbid
Sir Valentine her company and my court;
But fearing lest my jealous aim might err,
And so, unworthily, disgrace the man
(A rashness that I ever yet have shunn’d),
I gave him gentle looks, thereby to find
That which thyself hast now disclos’d to me.
And that thou mayst perceive my fear of this,
Knowing that tender youth is soon suggested,
I nightly lodge her in an upper tow’r,
The key whereof myself have ever kept;
And thence she cannot be convey’d away.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Know, noble lord, they have devis’d a mean
How he her chamber-window will ascend,
And with a corded ladder fetch her down;
For which the youthful lover now is gone,
And this way comes he with it presently,
Where (if it please you) you may intercept him.
But, good my lord, do it so cunningly
That my discovery be not aimed at:
For love of you, not hate unto my friend,
Hath made me publisher of this pretense.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Upon mine honor, he shall never know
That I had any light from thee of this.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Adieu, my lord, Sir Valentine is coming.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Sir Valentine, whither away so fast?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Please it your Grace, there is a messenger
That stays to bear my letters to my friends,
And I am going to deliver them.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Be they of much import?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: The tenure of them doth but signify
My health and happy being at your court.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Nay then no matter; stay with me a while;
I am to break with thee of some affairs
That touch me near, wherein thou must be secret.
’Tis not unknown to thee that I have sought
To match my friend Sir Thurio to my daughter.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: I know it well, my lord, and sure the match
Were rich and honorable; besides, the gentleman
Is full of virtue, bounty, worth, and qualities
Beseeming such a wife as your fair daughter.
Cannot your Grace win her to fancy him?

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: No, trust me, she is peevish, sullen, froward,
Proud, disobedient, stubborn, lacking duty,
Neither regarding that she is my child,
Nor fearing me as if I were her father;
And may I say to thee, this pride of hers
(Upon advice) hath drawn my love from her,
And where I thought the remnant of mine age
Should have been cherish’d by her child-like duty,
I now am full resolv’d to take a wife,
And turn her out to who will take her in:
Then let her beauty be her wedding-dow’r,
For me and my possessions she esteems not.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: What would your Grace have me to do in this?

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: There is a lady in Milano here
Whom I affect; but she is nice and coy,
And nought esteems my aged eloquence.
Now therefore would I have thee to my tutor
(For long agone I have forgot to court;
Besides, the fashion of the time is chang’d)
How and which way I may bestow myself
To be regarded in her sun-bright eye.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Win her with gifts, if she respect not words:
Dumb jewels often in their silent kind
More than quick words do move a woman’s mind.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: But she did scorn a present that I sent her.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: A woman sometime scorns what best contents her.
Send her another; never give her o’er,
For scorn at first makes after-love the more.
If she do frown, ’tis not in hate of you,
But rather to beget more love in you.
If she do chide, ’tis not to have you gone,
For why, the fools are mad, if left alone.
Take no repulse, what ever she doth say;
For “get you gone,” she doth not mean “away!”
Flatter and praise, commend, extol their graces;
Though ne’er so black, say they have angels’ faces.
That man that hath a tongue, I say is no man,
If with his tongue he cannot win a woman.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: But she I mean is promis’d by her friends
Unto a youthful gentleman of worth,
And kept severely from resort of men,
That no man hath access by day to her.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Why then I would resort to her by night.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Ay, but the doors be lock’d, and keys kept safe,
That no man hath recourse to her by night.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: What lets but one may enter at her window?

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Her chamber is aloft, far from the ground,
And built so shelving that one cannot climb it
Without apparent hazard of his life.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Why then a ladder, quaintly made of cords,
To cast up, with a pair of anchoring hooks,
Would serve to scale another Hero’s tow’r,
So bold Leander would adventure it.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Now as thou art a gentleman of blood,
Advise me where I may have such a ladder.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: When would you use it? Pray, sir, tell me that.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: This very night; for Love is like a child,
That longs for every thing that he can come by.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: By seven a’ clock I’ll get you such a ladder.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: But hark thee: I will go to her alone.
How shall I best convey the ladder thither?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: It will be light, my lord, that you may bear it
Under a cloak that is of any length.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: A cloak as long as thine will serve the turn?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Ay, my good lord.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Then let me see thy cloak—
I’ll get me one of such another length.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Why, any cloak will serve the turn, my lord.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: How shall I fashion me to wear a cloak?
I pray thee let me feel thy cloak upon me.
What letter is this same? What’s here? “To Silvia”?
And here an engine fit for my proceeding!
I’ll be so bold to break the seal for once.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: And why not death, rather than living torment?
To die is to be banish’d from myself,
And Silvia is myself: banish’d from her
Is self from self, a deadly banishment.
What light is light, if Silvia be not seen?
What joy is joy, if Silvia be not by?
Unless it be to think that she is by,
And feed upon the shadow of perfection.
Except I be by Silvia in the night,
There is no music in the nightingale;
Unless I look on Silvia in the day,
There is no day for me to look upon.
She is my essence, and I leave to be,
If I be not by her fair influence
Foster’d, illumin’d, cherish’d, kept alive.
I fly not death, to fly his deadly doom:
Tarry I here, I but attend on death,
But fly I hence, I fly away from life.

speech.speaker: LAUNCE.
speech.line: I am but a fool, look you, and yet I have the wit to think my master is a kind of a knave; but that’s all one, if he be but one knave. He lives not now that knows me to be in love, yet I am in love, but a team of horse shall not pluck that from me; nor who ’tis I love; and yet ’tis a woman; but what woman, I will not tell myself; and yet ’tis a milkmaid; yet ’tis not a maid, for she hath had gossips; yet ’tis a maid, for she is her master’s maid, and serves for wages. She hath more qualities than a water-spaniel, which is much in a bare Christian.

Here is the cate-log of her condition. “Inprimis, She can fetch and carry.” Why, a horse can do no more; nay, a horse cannot fetch, but only carry, therefore is she better than a jade. “Item, She can milk.” Look you, a sweet virtue in a maid with clean hands.

speech.speaker: LAUNCE.
speech.line: Ay, that she can.

speech.speaker: LAUNCE.
speech.line: Now will he be swing’d for reading my letter—an unmannerly slave, that will thrust himself into secrets. I’ll after, to rejoice in the boy’s correction.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Sir Thurio, fear not but that she will love you
Now Valentine is banish’d from her sight.

speech.speaker: THU.
speech.line: Since his exile she hath despis’d me most,
Forsworn my company, and rail’d at me,
That I am desperate of obtaining her.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: This weak impress of love is as a figure
Trenched in ice, which with an hour’s heat
Dissolves to water, and doth lose his form.
A little time will melt her frozen thoughts,
And worthless Valentine shall be forgot.

speech.speaker: 1. OUT.
speech.line: Fellows, stand fast; I see a passenger.

speech.speaker: 2. OUT.
speech.line: If there be ten, shrink not, but down with ’em.

speech.speaker: 3. OUT.
speech.line: Stand, sir, and throw us that you have about ye.
If not, we’ll make you sit, and rifle you.

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: Sir, we are undone; these are the villains
That all the travellers do fear so much.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: My friends—

speech.speaker: 1. OUT.
speech.line: That’s not so, sir; we are your enemies.

speech.speaker: 2. OUT.
speech.line: Peace! We’ll hear him.

speech.speaker: 3. OUT.
speech.line: Ay, by my beard, will we, for he is a proper man.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Then know that I have little wealth to lose.
A man I am cross’d with adversity;
My riches are these poor habiliments,
Of which if you should here disfurnish me,
You take the sum and substance that I have.

speech.speaker: 2. OUT.
speech.line: Whither travel you?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: To Verona.

speech.speaker: 1. OUT.
speech.line: Whence came you?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: From Milan.

speech.speaker: 3. OUT.
speech.line: Have you long sojourn’d there?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Some sixteen months, and longer might have stay’d,
If crooked fortune had not thwarted me.

speech.speaker: 1. OUT.
speech.line: What, were you banish’d thence?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: I was.

speech.speaker: 2. OUT.
speech.line: For what offense?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: For that which now torments me to rehearse:
I kill’d a man, whose death I much repent,
But yet I slew him manfully in fight,
Without false vantage, or base treachery.

speech.speaker: 1. OUT.
speech.line: Why, ne’er repent it, if it were done so.
But were you banish’d for so small a fault?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: I was, and held me glad of such a doom.

speech.speaker: 2. OUT.
speech.line: Have you the tongues?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: My youthful travel therein made me happy,
Or else I often had been miserable.

speech.speaker: 3. OUT.
speech.line: By the bare scalp of Robin Hood’s fat friar,
This fellow were a king for our wild faction!

speech.speaker: 1. OUT.
speech.line: We’ll have him. Sirs, a word.

speech.speaker: SPEED.
speech.line: Master, be one of them;
It’s an honorable kind of thievery.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Peace, villain.

speech.speaker: 2. OUT.
speech.line: Tell us this: have you any thing to take to?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Nothing but my fortune.

speech.speaker: 3. OUT.
speech.line: Know then, that some of us are gentlemen,
Such as the fury of ungovern’d youth
Thrust from the company of aweful men.
Myself was from Verona banished
For practicing to steal away a lady,
An heir, and near allied unto the Duke.

speech.speaker: 2. OUT.
speech.line: And I from Mantua, for a gentleman,
Who, in my mood, I stabb’d unto the heart.

speech.speaker: 1. OUT.
speech.line: And I for such like petty crimes as these.
But to the purpose—for we cite our faults
That they may hold excus’d our lawless lives;
And partly, seeing you are beautified
With goodly shape, and by your own report
A linguist, and a man of such perfection
As we do in our quality much want—

speech.speaker: 2. OUT.
speech.line: Indeed because you are a banish’d man,
Therefore, above the rest, we parley to you:
Are you content to be our general?
To make a virtue of necessity
And live as we do in this wilderness?

speech.speaker: 3. OUT.
speech.line: What say’st thou? Wilt thou be of our consort?
Say “ay” and be the captain of us all:
We’ll do thee homage and be rul’d by thee,
Love thee as our commander and our king.

speech.speaker: 1. OUT.
speech.line: But if thou scorn our courtesy, thou diest.

speech.speaker: 2. OUT.
speech.line: Thou shalt not live to brag what we have offer’d.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: I take your offer, and will live with you,
Provided that you do no outrages
On silly women or poor passengers.

speech.speaker: 3. OUT.
speech.line: No, we detest such vile base practices.
Come, go with us, we’ll bring thee to our crews,
And show thee all the treasure we have got;
Which, with ourselves, all rest at thy dispose.

scene.line: But here comes Thurio. Now must we to her window,
And give some evening music to her ear.

speech.speaker: THU.
speech.line: How now, Sir Proteus, are you crept before us?

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Ay, gentle Thurio, for you know that love
Will creep in service where it cannot go.

speech.speaker: THU.
speech.line: Ay, but I hope, sir, that you love not here.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Sir, but I do; or else I would be hence.

speech.speaker: THU.
speech.line: Who? Silvia?

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Ay, Silvia—for your sake.

speech.speaker: THU.
speech.line: I thank you for your own. Now, gentlemen,
Let’s tune, and to it lustily a while.

stagedir.dir: Enter at one side Host, Julia in boy’s clothes, as Sebastian.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Hark, hark!

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: Is he among these?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Ay; but peace, let’s hear ’em.

stagedir.dir: Enter Silvia above at her window.

speech.line: ’Twere false, if I should speak it;
For I am sure she is not buried.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Say that she be; yet Valentine thy friend
Survives; to whom (thyself art witness)
I am betroth’d; and art thou not asham’d
To wrong him with thy importunacy?

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: I likewise hear that Valentine is dead.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: And so suppose am I; for in his grave
Assure thyself my love is buried.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Sweet lady, let me rake it from the earth.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Go to thy lady’s grave and call hers thence,
Or at the least, in hers sepulchre thine.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: He heard not that.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Madam, if your heart be so obdurate,
Vouchsafe me yet your picture for my love,
The picture that is hanging in your chamber;
To that I’ll speak, to that I’ll sigh and weep;
For since the substance of your perfect self
Is else devoted, I am but a shadow;
And to your shadow will I make true love.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: If ’twere a substance, you would sure deceive it,
And make it but a shadow, as I am.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: I am very loath to be your idol, sir;
But since your falsehood shall become you well
To worship shadows and adore false shapes,
Send to me in the morning, and I’ll send it;
And so, good rest.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: As wretches have o’ernight
That wait for execution in the morn.

speech.speaker: EGL.
speech.line: This is the hour that Madam Silvia
Entreated me to call and know her mind.
There’s some great matter she’ld employ me in.
Madam, madam!

stagedir.dir: Enter Silvia above at her window.

speech.speaker: LAUNCE.
speech.line: When a man’s servant shall play the cur with him, look you, it goes hard: one that I brought up of a puppy; one that I sav’d from drowning, when three or four of his blind brothers and sisters went to it. I have taught him, even as one would say precisely, “Thus I would teach a dog.” I was sent to deliver him as a present to Mistress Silvia from my master; and I came no sooner into the dining-chamber but he steps me to her trencher and steals her capon’s leg. O, ’tis a foul thing when a cur cannot keep himself in all companies! I would have (as one should say) one that takes upon him to be a dog indeed, to be, as it were, a dog at all things. If I had not had more wit than he, to take a fault upon me that he did, I think verily he had been hang’d for’t; sure as I live he had suffer’d for’t. You shall judge: he thrusts me himself into the company of three or four gentleman-like dogs, under the Duke’s table. He had not been there (bless the mark!) a pissing-while, but all the chamber smelt him. “Out with the dog,” says one. “What cur is that?” says another. “Whip him out,” says the third. “Hang him up,” says the Duke. I, having been acquainted with the smell before, knew it was Crab, and goes me to the fellow that whips the dogs: “Friend,” quoth I, “you mean to whip the dog?” “Ay, marry, do I,” quoth he. “You do him the more wrong,” quoth I, “’twas I did the thing you wot of.” He makes me no more ado, but whips me out of the chamber. How many masters would do this for his servant? Nay, I’ll be sworn, I have sat in the stocks for puddings he hath stol’n, otherwise he had been executed; I have stood on the pillory for geese he hath kill’d, otherwise he had suffer’d for’t. Thou think’st not of this now. Nay, I remember the trick you serv’d me, when I took my leave of Madam Silvia. Did not I bid thee still mark me, and do as I do? When didst thou see me heave up my leg and make water against a gentlewoman’s farthingale? Didst thou ever see me do such a trick?

stagedir.dir: Enter Proteus, Julia disguised as Sebastian.

scene.line: Where have you been these two days loitering?

speech.speaker: LAUNCE.
speech.line: Marry, sir, I carried Mistress Silvia the dog you bade me.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: And what says she to my little jewel?

speech.speaker: LAUNCE.
speech.line: Marry, she says your dog was a cur, and tells you currish thanks is good enough for such a present.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: But she receiv’d my dog?

speech.speaker: LAUNCE.
speech.line: No indeed did she not; here have I brought him back again.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: What, didst thou offer her this from me?

speech.speaker: LAUNCE.
speech.line: Ay, sir, the other squirrel was stol’n from me by the hangman’s boys in the market-place; and then I offer’d her mine own, who is a dog as big as ten of yours, and therefore the gift the greater.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Go, get thee hence, and find my dog again,
Or ne’er return again into my sight.
Away, I say! Stayest thou to vex me here?
Gentlewoman, good day; I pray you be my mean
To bring me where to speak with Madam Silvia.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: What would you with her, if that I be she?

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: If you be she, I do entreat your patience
To hear me speak the message I am sent on.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: From whom?

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: From my master, Sir Proteus, madam.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: O, he sends you for a picture?

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: Ay, madam.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Ursula, bring my picture there.
Go give your master this. Tell him from me,
One Julia, that his changing thoughts forget,
Would better fit his chamber than this shadow.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: Madam, please you peruse this letter—
Pardon me, madam, I have unadvis’d
Deliver’d you a paper that I should not:
This is the letter to your ladyship.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: I pray thee let me look on that again.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: It may not be; good madam, pardon me.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: There, hold!
I will not look upon your master’s lines;
I know they are stuff’d with protestations,
And full of new-found oaths, which he will break
As easily as I do tear his paper.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: Madam, he sends your ladyship this ring.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: The more shame for him that he sends it me;
For I have heard him say a thousand times
His Julia gave it him at his departure:
Though his false finger have profan’d the ring,
Mine shall not do his Julia so much wrong.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: She thanks you.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: What say’st thou?

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: I thank you, madam, that you tender her.
Poor gentlewoman, my master wrongs her much.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Dost thou know her?

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: Almost as well as I do know myself.
To think upon her woes I do protest
That I have wept a hundred several times.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Belike she thinks that Proteus hath forsook her?

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: I think she doth; and that’s her cause of sorrow.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Is she not passing fair?

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: She hath been fairer, madam, than she is:
When she did think my master lov’d her well,
She, in my judgment, was as fair as you;
But since she did neglect her looking-glass,
And threw her sun-expelling mask away,
The air hath starv’d the roses in her cheeks,
And pinch’d the lily-tincture of her face,
That now she is become as black as I.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: How tall was she?

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: About my stature; for at Pentecost,
When all our pageants of delight were play’d,
Our youth got me to play the woman’s part,
And I was trimm’d in Madam Julia’s gown,
Which served me as fit, by all men’s judgments,
As if the garment had been made for me;
Therefore I know she is about my height.
And at that time I made her weep agood,
For I did play a lamentable part.
Madam, ’twas Ariadne passioning
For Theseus’ perjury and unjust flight;
Which I so lively acted with my tears
That my poor mistress, moved therewithal,
Wept bitterly; and would I might be dead
If I in thought felt not her very sorrow.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: She is beholding to thee, gentle youth.
Alas, poor lady, desolate and left!
I weep myself to think upon thy words.
Here, youth, there is my purse; I give thee this
For thy sweet mistress’ sake, because thou lov’st her.
Farewell.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: And she shall thank you for’t, if e’er you know her.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Amen, amen! Go on, good Eglamour,
Out at the postern by the abbey wall;
I fear I am attended by some spies.

speech.speaker: EGL.
speech.line: Fear not: the forest is not three leagues off;
If we recover that, we are sure enough.

scene.scenelocation: Milan. A room in the Duke’s palace.

stagedir.dir: Enter Thurio, Proteus, Julia disguised as Sebastian.

scene.line: But love will not be spurr’d to what it loathes.

speech.speaker: THU.
speech.line: What says she to my face?

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: She says it is a fair one.

speech.speaker: THU.
speech.line: Nay then the wanton lies; my face is black.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: But pearls are fair; and the old saying is,
Black men are pearls in beauteous ladies’ eyes.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: ’Tis true, such pearls as put out ladies’ eyes,
For I had rather wink than look on them.

speech.speaker: THU.
speech.line: How likes she my discourse?

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Ill, when you talk of war.

speech.speaker: THU.
speech.line: But well, when I discourse of love and peace.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: But better indeed, when you hold your peace.

speech.speaker: THU.
speech.line: What says she to my valor?

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: O, sir, she makes no doubt of that.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: She needs not, when she knows it cowardice.

speech.speaker: THU.
speech.line: What says she to my birth?

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: That you are well deriv’d.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: True: from a gentleman to a fool.

speech.speaker: THU.
speech.line: Considers she my possessions?

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: O ay; and pities them.

speech.speaker: THU.
speech.line: Wherefore?

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: That such an ass should owe them.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: That they are out by lease.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: Here comes the Duke.

speech.speaker: THU.
speech.line: Why, this it is to be a peevish girl,
That flies her fortune when it follows her.
I’ll after, more to be reveng’d on Eglamour
Than for the love of reckless Silvia.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: And I will follow, more to cross that love
Than hate for Silvia, that is gone for love.

speech.speaker: 1. OUT.
speech.line: Come, come,
Be patient; we must bring you to our captain.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: A thousand more mischances than this one
Have learn’d me how to brook this patiently.

speech.speaker: 2. OUT.
speech.line: Come, bring her away.

speech.speaker: 1. OUT.
speech.line: Where is the gentleman that was with her?

speech.speaker: 3. OUT.
speech.line: Being nimble-footed, he hath outrun us,
But Moyses and Valerius follow him.
Go thou with her to the west end of the wood;
There is our captain. We’ll follow him that’s fled—
The thicket is beset, he cannot scape.

speech.speaker: 1. OUT.
speech.line: Come, I must bring you to our captain’s cave.
Fear not; he bears an honorable mind,
And will not use a woman lawlessly.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: O Valentine, this I endure for thee!

scene.scenelocation: The frontiers of Mantua. Another part of the forest between Milan and Verona.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Madam, this service I have done for you
(Though you respect not aught your servant doth)
To hazard life, and rescue you from him
That would have forc’d your honor and your love.
Vouchsafe me, for my meed, but one fair look:
A smaller boon than this I cannot beg,
And less than this, I am sure you cannot give.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: How like a dream is this! I see, and hear:
Love, lend me patience to forbear a while.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: O miserable, unhappy that I am!

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Unhappy were you, madam, ere I came;
But by my coming I have made you happy.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: By thy approach thou mak’st me most unhappy.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: And me, when he approacheth to your presence.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Had I been seized by a hungry lion,
I would have been a breakfast to the beast
Rather than have false Proteus rescue me.
O heaven be judge how I love Valentine,
Whose life’s as tender to me as my soul!
And full as much (for more there cannot be)
I do detest false perjur’d Proteus.
Therefore be gone, solicit me no more.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: What dangerous action, stood it next to death,
Would I not undergo for one calm look?
O, ’tis the curse in love, and still approv’d,
When women cannot love where they’re belov’d!

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: When Proteus cannot love where he’s belov’d!
Read over Julia’s heart (thy first best love),
For whose dear sake thou didst then rend thy faith
Into a thousand oaths; and all those oaths
Descended into perjury, to love me.
Thou hast no faith left now, unless thou’dst two,
And that’s far worse than none: better have none
Than plural faith, which is too much by one.
Thou counterfeit to thy true friend!

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: In love
Who respects friend?

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: All men but Proteus.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Nay, if the gentle spirit of moving words
Can no way change you to a milder form,
I’ll woo you like a soldier, at arm’s end,
And love you ’gainst the nature of love—force ye.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: O heaven!

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: I’ll force thee yield to my desire.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Ruffian! Let go that rude uncivil touch,
Thou friend of an ill fashion!

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Valentine!

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Thou common friend, that’s without faith or love,
For such is a friend now! Treacherous man,
Thou hast beguil’d my hopes! Nought but mine eye
Could have persuaded me; now I dare not say
I have one friend alive; thou wouldst disprove me.
Who should be trusted, when one’s right hand
Is perjured to the bosom? Proteus,
I am sorry I must never trust thee more,
But count the world a stranger for thy sake.
The private wound is deepest: O time most accurst!
’Mongst all foes that a friend should be the worst!

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: My shame and guilt confounds me.
Forgive me, Valentine; if hearty sorrow
Be a sufficient ransom for offense,
I tender’t here: I do as truly suffer
As e’er I did commit.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Then I am paid;
And once again I do receive thee honest.
Who by repentance is not satisfied
Is nor of heaven nor earth, for these are pleas’d;
By penitence th’ Eternal’s wrath’s appeas’d:
And that my love may appear plain and free,
All that was mine in Silvia I give thee.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: O me unhappy!

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Look to the boy.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Why, boy! Why, wag! How now? What’s the matter? Look up; speak.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: O good sir, my master charg’d me to deliver a ring to Madam Silvia, which (out of my neglect) was never done.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Where is that ring, boy?

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: Here ’tis; this is it.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: How? Let me see.
Why, this is the ring I gave to Julia.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: O, cry you mercy, sir, I have mistook;
This is the ring you sent to Silvia.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: But how cam’st thou by this ring? At my depart
I gave this unto Julia.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: And Julia herself did give it me,
And Julia herself hath brought it hither.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: How? Julia?

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: Behold her that gave aim to all thy oaths,
And entertain’d ’em deeply in her heart.
How oft hast thou with perjury cleft the root?
O Proteus, let this habit make thee blush!
Be thou asham’d that I have took upon me
Such an immodest raiment—if shame live
In a disguise of love!
It is the lesser blot, modesty finds,
Women to change their shapes than men their minds.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Than men their minds? ’Tis true. O heaven, were man
But constant, he were perfect; that one error
Fills him with faults; makes him run through all th’ sins:
Inconstancy falls off ere it begins.
What is in Silvia’s face, but I may spy
More fresh in Julia’s with a constant eye?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Come, come, a hand from either.
Let me be blest to make this happy close;
’Twere pity two such friends should be long foes.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Bear witness, heaven, I have my wish forever.

speech.speaker: JUL.
speech.line: And I mine.

speech.speaker: ALL OUTLAWS
speech.line: A prize, a prize, a prize!

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Forbear, forbear, I say; it is my lord the Duke.
Your Grace is welcome to a man disgrac’d,
Banished Valentine.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Sir Valentine!

speech.speaker: THU.
speech.line: Yonder is Silvia; and Silvia’s mine.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Thurio, give back, or else embrace thy death;
Come not within the measure of my wrath.
Do not name Silvia thine; if once again,
Milan shall not hold thee. Here she stands,
Take but possession of her with a touch:
I dare thee but to breathe upon my love.

speech.speaker: THU.
speech.line: Sir Valentine, I care not for her, I;
I hold him but a fool that will endanger
His body for a girl that loves him not.
I claim her not, and therefore she is thine.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: The more degenerate and base art thou
To make such means for her as thou hast done,
And leave her on such slight conditions.
Now, by the honor of my ancestry,
I do applaud thy spirit, Valentine,
And think thee worthy of an empress’ love.
Know then, I here forget all former griefs,
Cancel all grudge, repeal thee home again,
Plead a new state in thy unrivall’d merit,
To which I thus subscribe: Sir Valentine,
Thou art a gentleman and well deriv’d,
Take thou thy Silvia, for thou hast deserv’d her.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: I thank your Grace; the gift hath made me happy.
I now beseech you (for your daughter’s sake)
To grant one boon that I shall ask of you.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: I grant it (for thine own) what e’er it be.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: These banish’d men, that I have kept withal,
Are men endu’d with worthy qualities.
Forgive them what they have committed here,
And let them be recall’d from their exile;
They are reformed, civil, full of good,
And fit for great employment, worthy lord.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Thou hast prevail’d, I pardon them and thee;
Dispose of them as thou know’st their deserts.
Come, let us go, we will include all jars
With triumphs, mirth, and rare solemnity.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: And as we walk along, I dare be bold
With our discourse to make your Grace to smile.
What think you of this page, my lord?

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: I think the boy hath grace in him; he blushes.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: I warrant you, my lord—more grace than boy.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: What mean you by that saying?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Please you, I’ll tell you as we pass along,
That you will wonder what hath fortuned.
Come, Proteus, ’tis your penance but to hear
The story of your loves discovered;
That done, our day of marriage shall be yours,
One feast, one house, one mutual happiness.
